newsitem.title: JAPAN: Fannie Mae targets Japanese investors.
newsitem.headline: Fannie Mae targets Japanese investors.

text.p: As cash-rich Japanese hunger for higher yields at a time of ultra-low domestic interest rates, U.S. mortgage group Fannie Mae announced Tuesday that it was targeting Japanese investors.

Fannie Mae, formally the Federal National Mortgage Association, is a U.S. government-sponsored enterprise that purchases mortgages from banks and packages them for sale to individual investors. Its creation has sharply increased the mortgage money available to U.S. homebuyers.
The programme in Japan is the first outside the United States.
"We're very well aware of (Japanese investors') appetite for higher-yielding investments in yen," James Johnson, chief executive officer at Fannie Mae, said in an interview.
"We're a very high-quality issuer ... with great liquidity," Johnson said. "We're looking very carefully at increasing opportunities to issue in yen."
Fannie Mae said it was planning to develop the programme by early next year.
